sn35.105:1.1: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what, do pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
sn35.105:2.1: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”
sn35.105:3.1: “Mendicants, when there’s an eye, because of grasping the eye, pleasure and pain arise in oneself. …
sn35.105:3.2: When there’s a mind, because of grasping the mind, pleasure and pain arise in oneself.
sn35.105:3.4: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
sn35.105:5.1: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn35.105:7.1: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
sn35.105:17.1: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn35.105:19.1: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
sn35.105:21.1: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
sn35.105:21.2: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
sn35.105:21.3: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
